channel.title: An answer to a lot of questions here
channel.description:
Please check [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page]Wikipedia[/url] before posting here, as it has a lot of information some of you might find interesting/useful.
Thank you for your time.
Whoops, I locked instead of a sticky.

item.title: An answer to a lot of questions here
item.dc:creator: @akl akl
item.description:
@akl wrote:

JaydenD12:

I tried using references from Wikipedia for my assignment, and I failed my assignment cause Wikipedia isn’t a stable source.

I’ve noticed that teachers degrade all the students who just c&p off wikipedia because, let’s be honest, almost everyone is spitting the same bullshit.
So perhaps many people in your class used Wikipedia, including you.

item.title: An answer to a lot of questions here
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Life Java Is My Life™
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Life wrote:

Umm, I’m pretty sure users’ can edit wikipedia and submit entries but, I think when someone changes the text to something only they can view it. Also members can submit so if you search a celeberity only good things are written about them reason being they pay someone to write one for them.

ZeroFreeze - www.howstuffworks.com is amazing. I recomend it to anyone with hard homework. It doesn’t give awnsers it just tells you how to solve you problem/equation/whatever.

Read full topic

item.title: An answer to a lot of questions here
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

I love how the recent replies in this topic just reiterate the initial replies. It’s as if I didn’t understand the information on the first page, so I need reassurance from the second.

My teachers have used Wikipedia for general information, but to get the core information, and all of the intricate details we may use encyclopedias, or other more reliable sources of information. Like this thing… What’s it called? Or right, a book. So this topic may help people get an understanding of the subject they’re researching, but it might also give them uncertainties.

I’d also like to comment that looking on Wikipedia may be more reliable than here.

Read full topic

item.title: An answer to a lot of questions here
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

ikick221:

how about you all delete the spam and lock it

Discussion about wikipedia could take place here, for example have you heard of Wikihow? It’s a collection of user created guides to activites like blowing smoke rings, winning at stuff, skateboarding etc…Anything that takes skill. Good shit man. Or we could talk about whatever we want really as long as it’s related to the past post in the thread and not blatantly disrespectful. Like, BobDole is a chill dude, man, because he hasn’t locked this thread and I’m posting here right now.

Read full topic

item.title: An answer to a lot of questions here
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Reliability of Wikipedia

The reliability of Wikipedia (predominantly of the English-language edition) has been frequently questioned and often assessed. The reliability has been tested statistically, through comparative review, analysis of the historical patterns, and strengths and weaknesses inherent in the editing process unique to Wikipedia. Incidents of conflicted editing, and the use of Wikipedia for 'revenge editing' (inserting false, defamatory or biased statements into biographies) have attracted publicity.[2

Read full topic
item.source: An answer to a lot of questions here
